name: Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture
summary: The Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer (BSD) conjecture relates the number of rational solutions to an elliptic curve to a property of the curve's L-function at \(s=1\). Specifically, it states that the rank of an elliptic curve (the number of independent rational solutions) is equal to the "order of vanishing" of its L-function at \(s=1\). This is a central problem in number theory and one of the Clay Mathematics Institute's Millennium Prize Problems.Â
head: The L-function \(L(E,s)\) has a zero of order \(r\) at the central point \(s=1\)
tail: The Mordell-Weil group of rational points \(E(\mathbb{Q})\) has rank \(r\).
kwds: Lists of unsolved problems in mathematics
